title: 103_s2361
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians Act of 1994". The Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians, along with other recognized tribes, are descendants of signatories to historical treaties with the United States. The Burt Lake Band consists of over 600 eligible members. The Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians, with over 600 eligible members, resides close to their ancestral homeland in Cheboygan County, Michigan. The Band continues to exist with a viable tribal government and was part of the Northern Michigan Ottawa Association, which successfully submitted a land claim with the Indian Claims Commission. The Band carried out governmental functions through the Association between 1948 and 1975. In 1975, the Northern Michigan Ottawa Association submitted a petition under the Indian Reorganization Act to form a government on behalf of the Band, but the Bureau of Indian Affairs did not act on it. The Band has had continuous dealings with the Federal Government, the government of Michigan, and political subdivisions of the State since 1836. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Band" refers to the Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians. The term "member" refers to any individual enrolled in the Band. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. Federal recognition of the Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians is reaffirmed by Congress. Federal laws applicable to Indians or Indian tribes will not apply if inconsistent with this Act. The Band and its members are eligible for all federal services and benefits provided to recognized Indians. The Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians, federally recognized, are eligible for federal services and benefits regardless of reservation status or member residence proximity to a reservation. The State of Michigan within a 70-mile radius of the reservation boundaries is considered part of the reservation for service delivery purposes. Members of the Burt Lake Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians are eligible for federal services and benefits regardless of reservation status or proximity to a reservation. If a reservation is established after the enactment of this Act, the benefits will still apply. Services and benefits may also be provided to members outside the designated service area, unless prohibited by Federal law. SEC. 5. REAFFIRMATION OF RIGHTS. All rights and privileges of the Band and its members that were previously abrogated or diminished are hereby reaffirmed. Existing rights of the Tribe are not diminished by this Act. Legal or equitable claims to enforce any wrongfully denied rights are preserved. SEC. 6. TRIBAL LANDS. SEC. 6. TRIBAL LANDS. The tribal lands of the Band consist of all real property held by or in trust for the Band. The Secretary acquires real property for the Band, which is held in trust by the United States for the Band's benefit and becomes part of the Band's reservation. SEC. 7. MEMBERSHIP. The Band must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 18 months of this Act's enactment, including all current members. The Band, in consultation with the Secretary, will determine membership qualifications. The Secretary will publish notice of the membership roll in the Federal Register. The Band will maintain the membership roll to ensure it is up to date.

SEC. 8. CONSTITUTION AND GOVERNING BODY. The Band must conduct elections to adopt a new constitution within 2 years of this Act's enactment. Until then, the current governing documents will serve as interim. Once a new constitution is adopted, elections for officials must be held within 180 days. The Band must conduct elections by secret ballot to elect officials as per the governing constitution. Interim governments will include existing governing bodies until new officials are elected.
